_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc., Gardena Facility has established a Risk Management Plan according to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) and Federal EPA Risk Management Plan regulations for the Warehousing and Repacking Operations to enhance its safety practices.  Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc. management is extremely cautious in the handling of all chemicals and is very diligent about safety for its employees.  



Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc., policy is to conduct all operations in a safe and conscientious manner to prevent accidental releases of any hazardous material, including substances regulated through the California Accidental Release Prevention Program and Federal EPA Risk Management Plan.  Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc. trains its employees to properly handle, transfer, and store hazardous materials, to minimize the possibility of adversely affecting its worker's health, the workplace, the public, and the environment.  The Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc. release prevention policy is implemented through the management system contained in its RMP.



Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc. does not maintain an emergency response team.  However, there are HAZWOPER trained employees onsite available to assess and handle spills and cleanup where necessary.  In case of an emergency, Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc. non-HAZWOPER trained employees are expected to evacuate to the designated evacuation areas and to remain away from all structures.  The most senior person on site will call 9-1-1 to summon assistance from the local authorities.  The Emergency Action Plan and Spill Reporting Requirements documents list the reporting requirements in the event of a hazardous material release.







Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc., Gardena Facility Warehousing and Repacking Operations



The Warehousing and Repacking Operations at the Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc., Gardena Facil

ity is used to receive, repack, and transport chemicals and other materials.  The received chemicals are manually repacked by trained plant personnel.





Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc., Gardena Facility has an RMP program in place to manage the handling of hazardous materials.  The program includes strict requirements for written operating and maintenance procedures, employee participation, personnel training, equipment maintenance, incident investigation, process hazard analysis, management of change, pre-startup safety review, hot work, contractor safety, and periodic audit of program elements.  Management of change element addresses proper implementation of system updates to ensure that all changes are reviewed properly by knowledgeable persons, all engineering documents and operating procedures reflect the change, and personnel are trained on the change.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being utilized.  





Five-Year Accident History



There have been no reportable accidents involving a regulated substance at the Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc., Gardena Facility within the past five years.





Emergency Response Program



Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc. does not maintain an emergency response team.  However, there are HAZWOPER trained employees onsite available to assess and handle spills and cleanup where necessary.  In case of an emergency, Spectrum Laboratory Products, Inc. non-HAZWOPER trained employees are expected to evacuate to the designated evacuation areas and to remain away from all structures.  The most senior person on site will call 9-1-1 to summon assistance from the local authorities.  The Emergency Action Plan and Spill Reporting Requirements documents list the reporting requirements in the event of a hazardous material release.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Reco
mmendations issued as part of the recent process hazard analysis and seismic assessment are currently being reviewed and will be addressed by January 10, 2018.
